data.text: As a direct result of the pandemic, banks’ return on equity fell from 5.2% at the end of 2019 to 2.1% in 2020. The crisis further highlighted weaknesses in banks’ asset quality, profitability, cost efficiency and the sustainability of their business models. https://t.co/i3NJw15HU2

Banks strengthened their capital levels in 2020: their Common Equity Tier 1 capital ratio increased slightly from 2019 and stood at 15.2% in the third quarter of 2020. This was partly due to the extraordinary relief measures taken in response to the crisis. https://t.co/j2krnB1zH4

Our supervisory focus shifted rapidly in 2020: we offered temporary capital and operational relief to banks so that they could continue lending to households and firms. Read more in the ECB Annual Report 2020 on supervisory activities https://t.co/R90MJkZtOs https://t.co/OBBCIapW5b

Watch: Chief Economist Philip R. Lane in an interview with @AnnetteCNBC on the pace of asset purchases, the economic impact of renewed lockdowns and the outlook for global recovery https://t.co/tSe19HXU7f https://t.co/JbT1n7LqJD

Right now: Supervisory Board Chair Andrea Enria in a hearing at the European Parliament’s Economic and Monetary Affairs Committee.
Watch the discussion https://t.co/t7jF7F1YEb
Read the introductory statement https://t.co/IocvsWSnCy https://t.co/8e4Fe3BoKx

Register now and watch live tomorrow from 13:05 CET: Supervisory Board member Elizabeth McCaul speaks at the Economist #EconCroatia virtual event about the recovery and resilience fund and Croatia’s financial prospects after the pandemic https://t.co/GMdHggYFlG

Lagarde: Flexibility remains the PEPP’s most precious asset. It has allowed purchases to fluctuate over time, across asset classes and among countries to stave off risks to monetary policy transmission 4/4
Lagarde: The PEPP keeps financing conditions favourable, helping households to consume, firms to remain in business and governments to undertake the necessary fiscal actions 3/4
Lagarde: With the help of the PEPP, we have stabilised financial markets and prevented a full-blown financial meltdown with devastating consequences for the people of Europe 2/4

Our pandemic emergency purchase programme (PEPP) has provided crucial support to euro area citizens since its launch a year ago, writes President Christine @Lagarde in her ECB Blog post. While we’ve achieved a lot, we cannot be complacent https://t.co/exXxtMrUc3 1/4 https://t.co/3DQ2ItVJOK

Real capital stock growth decreased only moderately during the pandemic in the euro area. There are two main reasons behind this limited decline: investment fell less than expected and capital depreciation dropped temporarily. Read more https://t.co/BFNNiqXpSQ #EconomicBulletin
Euro area monthly balance of payments (Jan 2021) https://t.co/cPuaDPU27V

This happens as banknotes are used as a store of value as well as a means of payment, both inside and outside the eurozone. Throughout 2020 people reacted as they often do during crises and stored up cash as a precaution. Read more https://t.co/LNXdeUZ8VZ #EconomicBulletin 2/2

In 2020 the value of euro banknotes in circulation went up by 11% to €1.435 trillion, while people used cash less often for everyday payments. This so-called paradox of banknotes has been observed over the past decade, and more intensely during the pandemic #EconomicBulletin 1/2 https://t.co/pOPLBQe8xt

Today we mark the International Day for the Elimination of Racial Discrimination. There is no place for racism at the ECB, in the EU or anywhere else. We have a responsibility to stand up against intolerant attitudes. 

How we #FightRacism at the ECB https://t.co/RuPcSuV3W2 https://t.co/LLb6ZWgZgx
Best practices applied by financial market infrastructures in their business continuity plans during the COVID-19 pandemic https://t.co/EH7NDUQPtg

We need progress towards a European Deposit Insurance Scheme, tools for the failure of small and medium-sized banks and rebalanced buffer requirements, says Vice-President Luis de Guindos, looking at the achievements and challenges of the banking union https://t.co/rITIHFxwdR https://t.co/Ut92BW2Bsj

Working paper: Forbearance vs foreclosure in a general equilibrium model
https://t.co/26YUiYFnxQ
Working paper: Networking the Yield Curve - Implications for Monetary Policy https://t.co/Fcc9WiIbUh

On 15 April 2021 we will start publishing compounded €STR average rates and a compounded €STR index. Want to find out more about how we calculate the data and when they get published? Read the press release https://t.co/4zxDhjc9IG https://t.co/clF4micqbX

We must learn from the great financial crisis, says Supervisory Board member Elizabeth McCaul. If banks do not prepare proactively and postpone credit quality assessments, non-performing loans will increase and amplify the shock, delaying the recovery https://t.co/qgShU6XNuS https://t.co/xALWLzoktB

Lagarde: Decisive action in other policy areas to support the recovery remains essential. The strength of Europe’s crisis response depended and still depends on the strength of national and European responses across all policy areas: monetary, fiscal, supervisory and regulatory.

Lagarde: The PEPP is not the only tool we are using to support favourable financing conditions during the pandemic period. The third series of targeted longer-term refinancing operations (TLTRO III) remains an attractive source of funding for banks.

Lagarde: One year after the successful launch of the pandemic emergency purchase programme (PEPP), purchases will be conducted at a significantly higher pace over the next quarter than during the first months of 2021, in order to prevent a tightening of financing conditions.

Lagarde: Preserving favourable financing conditions over the pandemic period remains essential to reduce uncertainty and bolster confidence, thereby underpinning economic activity and safeguarding medium-term price stability.

Lagarde: The risks surrounding the euro area growth outlook over the medium term are more balanced thanks to better prospects for the global economy. Downside risks remain in the near term due to the spread of the virus and the implications for economic and financial conditions.
Introductory statement by President Christine @Lagarde at a hearing of the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs of the European Parliament https://t.co/v6w4Gxwwzr

Live now: President @Lagarde speaks before the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs of the @Europarl_EN and answers questions from its members. Follow here https://t.co/6N9NXAwriv
@EP_Economics https://t.co/nVlYDiQv3O

De Guindos: These results underline the crucial and urgent need to transition to a greener economy, not only to ensure that the targets of the Paris Agreement are met, but also to limit the long-run disruption to our economies, businesses and livelihoods 3/3

De Guindos: Climate change may represent a major source of systemic risk, particularly for banks with portfolios concentrated in certain economic sectors and, even more importantly, in specific geographical areas 2/3

The costs to banks and companies of adapting to green policies now are much lower than the future costs that may arise from severe natural disasters, writes Vice-President Luis de Guindos in his ECB Blog post on our first climate stress test https://t.co/TsnwqMkV84 1/3 https://t.co/osH9oA87Tg

The rapid rise in risk-free interest rates risked withdrawing policy support in the euro area prematurely, says Executive Board member @Isabel_Schnabel. The ECB will tolerate higher interest rates only if they do not endanger the economic recovery. 1/2 https://t.co/TiIdbG6rAm
⚡️Missed our live Twitter Q&A with ECB Executive Board member @FrankElderson? Catch up here! #AskECB https://t.co/cnhqe0XdCx
https://t.co/cKbzqk7WjD
Time to wrap up. Thanks a lot for your questions – I really enjoyed the chat and look forward to doing this again soon. Take care! #AskECB https://t.co/Uj3jpmRTTy

🇪🇺@FrankElderson: We use as much powder as needed to preserve favourable financing conditions. Based on an assessment of financing conditions and the inflation outlook, we expect PEPP purchases over the next quarter to be done at a significantly higher pace than before #AskECB https://t.co/SkyXrewyFg

🇪🇺@FrankElderson: We value all facets of diversity, incl. gender, nationality, religion, sexual orientation, ethnicity, age, cultural background and disability. Governments appoint the Executive Board. As supervisors, we push banks towards more diverse boards and staff #AskECB https://t.co/HZ8vuxs0aX

🇪🇺@FrankElderson: The Treaties require us to support the EU’s environmental objectives and policies when pursuing our mandate. But our actions must not prejudice our objective of price stability #AskECB https://t.co/YiGxs9eGiD

🇪🇺@FrankElderson: We must contribute to the success of climate change-related policies within our mandate and we are looking at various options as part of our #strategyreview. However, it is up to governments to make such policies #AskECB https://t.co/VUpkuxIDjn

🇪🇺@FrankElderson: I’m very excited that we are setting up the @ecb climate change centre and are currently recruiting its head. Once in place, the team will shape and steer the ECB’s climate agenda, working closely with staff throughout the ECB #AskECB https://t.co/8Ft18An6L7

🇪🇺@FrankElderson: In case of market failures, we @ecb are not obliged to adhere to market neutrality under all circumstances. In any case, market neutrality is not a legal concept. We will share the outcome of our discussions at the end of the #strategyreview #AskECB https://t.co/HuyaSeWjxZ

🇪🇺@FrankElderson: Companies indeed face severe challenges due to the ongoing pandemic. But markets do expect a strong rebound of the economy and rising corporate earnings, crucially supported by fiscal and monetary policy #AskECB https://t.co/fxvCZ8ws6W

🇪🇺@FrankElderson: The increase is precisely a reflection of the flexibility embedded in the PEPP. We have increased purchases to prevent a tightening of financing conditions, that would risk the return of inflation to pre-pandemic levels #AskECB https://t.co/pQv4wmju6Q

🇪🇺@FrankElderson: Climate is a topic dear to my heart. We need urgent action and we are committed to doing our part within our mandate. How to incorporate climate change in our tasks is a key part of our #strategyreview, reviewing also our concept of market neutrality #AskECB https://t.co/53sVqsW00Q

🇪🇺@FrankElderson: Tulips are beautiful flowers. For those who remember 17th century Tulip Mania, they also serve as a reminder of what can happen when prices don’t reflect intrinsic value #AskECB https://t.co/YJq5P6CgkU

🇪🇺@FrankElderson: Upstream: important benchmark rates that mark the starting point of our monetary policy transmission. Downstream: the financing conditions that are more relevant for households and firms but are only affected by our policy with a delay #AskECB https://t.co/P2dSFVzRV2

🇪🇺@FrankElderson Asset purchases can lead to higher asset prices but they’ve also helped to maintain millions of jobs. We're closely monitoring side effects of our measures and analyses have shown consistently that positive effects have exceeded negative ones #AskECB https://t.co/s0p4BHzmVy

🇪🇺@FrankElderson: It is true that pandemic-related supply constraints, among other factors, are expected to increase inflation during this year. However, our assessment is that underlying price pressures will remain muted due to weak demand and low wage pressures #AskECB https://t.co/lwee84px7h

🇪🇺@FrankElderson: Better disclosure and transparency on environmental risks has top priority over everything else so that consumers, investors, businesses and policymakers can take informed decisions for a more sustainable future #AskECB https://t.co/GMtZIti97o

🇪🇺@FrankElderson: Crypto-assets are volatile. They lack any intrinsic value and there is no reliable institution backing them. In contrast, a digital euro would offer Europeans the same level of confidence as with cash, since it would be backed by the ECB #AskECB https://t.co/qr1duR5B5P

🇪🇺@FrankElderson: We look at a number of indicators. To determine whether financing conditions are favourable, we look at their underlying drivers and how they develop over time, in combination with the inflation outlook #AskECB https://t.co/mRW4nsPBbe

🇪🇺@FrankElderson: Our forward guidance is clear on that: We expect interest rates to stay at their present level or lower until we see that inflation comes back to our objective of close to, but below, 2 per cent #AskECB https://t.co/YivKmU2pbe

🇪🇺@FrankElderson: Personally, I am very proud of my wife and our two great daughters! Professionally, I am honoured to work for Europe and committed to helping make the lives of Europeans better in this pandemic #AskECB https://t.co/58ID63ubj0

🇪🇺@FrankElderson: Inflation increased sharply in January and February and is likely to go up further in the coming months. This is mainly due to transitory factors, which we look through. Underlying inflation remains subdued owing to weak demand and economic slack #AskECB https://t.co/Ri539kRmlJ

🇪🇺@FrankElderson: The Eurosystem is preparing the measurement of greenhouse gas emissions and other sustainable and responsible investment-related metrics of these Eurosystem portfolios, including the use of some specialised data providers #AskECB https://t.co/fayZOfaymU

🇪🇺@FrankElderson: While the evidence is that our policies are very effective we certainly also have possible side effects on our radar. The two-tier system is a case in point where we have reacted to mitigate the potential side effects of our negative rate policy on banks #AskECB https://t.co/os2ZarZwOg
Hello, this is @FrankElderson, Executive Board member at the ECB. I’m looking forward to answering your questions for the next 45 minutes or so. Join the conversation! #AskECB https://t.co/J1l1y2TQqn

The pandemic has been the hardest test for the banking union so far, says Supervisory Board Chair Andrea Enria. But it is also an opportunity for banks to become more efficient and to prepare for future challenges, such as climate-related risks https://t.co/LpfAMDCIx9 https://t.co/80u5IdTiyK

Lane: We need to offset the shock that the pandemic caused to inflation. We will provide enough monetary accommodation and keep financing conditions favourable until inflation path converges to our aim. Read the interview https://t.co/E1NTsEYKnD 3/3

Lane: We need to make sure that yield curves – which play an important role in determining overall financing conditions – do not move ahead of the economy. This is a shift in monetary policy away from focusing on just the short-term rate by looking at all financing conditions 2/3

Monetary and fiscal support can be quite extensive as it is only for a short period of time, says Chief Economist Philip R. Lane to the @FinancialTimes. It is important that we don’t amplify the temporary losses in the pandemic by being too reluctant with our policy support. https://t.co/HA1JxZqjAD

The ECB has an obligation to explore how it can contribute to combating climate change within its mandate, says Executive Board member @Isabel_Schnabel. While urgent policy action is necessary, this must not cast doubt on our commitment to price stability https://t.co/RfEiSprWOk https://t.co/z84XS0QLZ1

Panetta: Requiring more critical services to be provided by EU central counterparties (CCPs) would make our domestic clearing landscape more systemically important. This would require the EU dimension of CCP supervision to be scaled up. Read the speech https://t.co/vAmEnwSLK1 2/2

Brexit has showed the urgency to consider the extent to which the EU should depend on non-EU countries for critical market infrastructure, says Executive Board member Fabio Panetta. Euro-denominated central clearing must not be a source of instability in the euro area 1/2 https://t.co/M33JHfjFvJ
Working Paper: ECB-Global 2.0 - A global macroeconomic model with dominant-currency pricing, tariffs and trade diversion https://t.co/QsJ9Ivziju
Euro area bank interest rate statistics (Jan 2021) https://t.co/8Bbesq09O6
Euro area insurance corporation statistics (Q4 2020) https://t.co/cYyvC7qqGk
Results of the December 2020 survey on credit terms and conditions in euro-denominated securities financing and over-the-counter derivatives markets (SESFOD) https://t.co/ZQccW7Nw91

Panetta: Monetary policy is more effective if deployed in sync with other policies. Monetary, fiscal and structural policies must reinforce each other in order to cut slack and close the gap between saving and investment. Read the full speech https://t.co/BpGCjasDex 5/5

Panetta: By keeping nominal yields low for longer, we can provide a strong anchor to preserve favourable financing conditions. Improvements in the outlook will lower real interest rates, supporting confidence in a sustained return of inflation to our aim 3/5

Panetta: We will still face two prominent gaps that we need to close: the output gap and the inflation gap. And if we fail to do so with sufficient force we could inadvertently hold back economic growth and depress inflation for years to come 2/5
